Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Photolysis of environmentally-relevant organometallic compounds in aqueous matrices
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Environmental Chemical Sciences Program in the Division of Chemistry is funding Professor Lee Blaney of the University of Maryland, Baltimore County (UMBC) and Professor Katherine Squibb of the University of Maryland, Baltimore (UMB) to investigate the chemistry of organometallic substances in the environment. This project seeks to understand the environmental transformations of organometallic compounds due to direct and indirect solar photolysis. Organoarsenic, -platinum, -selenium, and -tin compounds are included in this research because they are widespread in environmental systems. Two PhD-level graduate students and a number of undergraduate assistants are involved with the associated research. The project team works with the UMBC Meyerhoff Scholars Program (MSP) and Center for Women in Technology (CWIT) to recruit students from underrepresented groups who are interested in environmental chemistry. In addition, the PIs partner with MSP, CWIT, and the UMBC Office of Undergraduate Education to engage students from underrepresented groups in workshops, seminars, and demonstrations, with a goal to promote undergraduate research and education in the environmental chemical sciences. Select aspects of the research are being incorporated into graduate level courses in Environmental Chemistry (UMBC) and Advanced Toxicology (UMB).

Advanced analytical methods are being developed using solid-phase extraction liquid chromatography tandem mass spectrometry (SPE-LC-MS/MS) for organometallics to enhance identification and quantitation of transformation products. The molar extinction coefficients and photo-transformation kinetics of eight organometallic substances are being determined across pH and wavelength gradients for direct and indirect photolysis mechanisms. Furthermore, the transformation pathways for these chemicals from the organic form to the base metal species are being identified. As the toxicity of organometallics and their base metals differ, a targeted bioassay approach is employed to demonstrate changes in toxicity with photolytic degradation. More specifically, the research aims include: (i)developing solid-phase extraction liquid chromatography electrospray ionization tandem mass spectrometry (SPE-LC-ESI-MS/MS) analytical methods for these organometallic species; (ii) measuring the transformation kinetics of the organometallic compounds of concern by direct and indirect photolysis in urban surface water; (iii)identifying transformation products formed through direct and indirect photolysis of targeted organometallic compounds and (iv) characterizing the residual biochemical activity of solutions containing organometallic compounds and phototransformation products using a targeted bioassay approach. This research approach is expected to improve understanding of the photochemical fate of organometallic chemicals in environmental systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Organometallic compounds are chemicals that include a metal atom covalently bound to a carbon atom. Due to the presence of the organic moiety and the metal atom, these chemicals participate in unique sorption, redox, and catalysis reactions. As a result, organometallics are widely applied in the biomedical, agricultural, and electrical fields as antibiotics, chemotherapy agents, antioxidants, pesticides, and semiconductors. The growing demand for organometallic chemicals is expected to proportionally increase the environmental load of these contaminants. The special properties of organometallics pose distinct environmental concerns. For example, select organotin compounds were banned for agricultural use in Germany and restricted in consumer products in the European Union due to genotoxicity, developmental toxicity, and endocrine disruption in marine organisms; however, several organotin compounds (e.g., azocyclotin, cyhexatin, and triphenyltin hydroxide) are still used as pesticides around the world. In the environment, these compounds may undergo a number of transformation reactions. Photochemical oxidation is a major abiotic process that governs the fate of organic contaminants in natural water; however, few studies have elucidated the photochemical transformation of organometallics.

The overall goal of this project was to describe the transformation of four classes of organometallic chemicals during direct and indirect photolysis. Direct photolysis occurs when the organometallic chemical absorbs sufficient energy (from light) to cause the rearrangement, cleavage, or formation of chemical bonds. Dissolved organic matter, which stems from the decay of plant and animal matter, can sensitize the formation of reactive species, such as hydroxyl radicals, singlet oxygen, and triplet dissolved organic matter. Indirect photolysis describes the reaction of these species with organometallic chemicals. To improve understanding of the fate of organometallic chemicals during direct and indirect photolysis, we investigated the following objectives:

1. Development of solid-phase extraction pretreatment protocols and liquid chromatography with electrospray ionization tandem mass spectrometry analytical methods to measure eight organometallic chemicals in water and wastewater samples;

2. Measurement of the molar absorption coefficients, quantum yields, second-order rate constants relevant to the transformation kinetics of the organometallic compounds of concern by direct and indirect photolysis in surface water;

3. Identification of the transformation products formed through direct and indirect photolysis of organo-arsenic, -selenium, and -tin compounds; and,

4. Characterization of the residual biochemical activity of solutions containing organometallic compounds and phototransformation products using a targeted bioassay approach.

Each objective generated intellectual merit related to the state of knowledge on organometallic fate in environmental systems. In Objective 1, we developed novel analytical methods to quantify the concentrations of organometallic chemicals to concentrations as low as 10 ng/L (with a 1000x enrichment factor during solid-phase extraction). These methods will prove useful to other researchers exploring various aspects of the environmental fate of organometallic chemicals. In Objective 2, we determined that organometallic chemicals absorbed more light and underwent faster phototransformation reactions compared to molecules where the metal atom was substituted with a carbon atom. These results suggest that the special properties of organometallic chemicals tend to decrease the half-life of organometallics in the environment, resulting in lower persistence and potential toxicity outcomes. The organo-arsenic, -selenium, and -tin chemicals demonstrated some class-specific properties that affected their reaction kinetics during direct and indirect photolysis with hydroxyl radicals, singlet oxygen, triplet dissolved organic matter, and reactive intermediates formed from reactive species sensitizers, probes, and quenchers. These results highlight the need to carefully consider the impacts of water quality and experimental conditions on organometallic phototransformation. In Objectives 3 and 4, the transformation products of organo-arsenic, -selenium, and -tin chemicals were identified to contain certain risks. In particular, the main phototransformation product of roxarsone (organoarsenic) was arsenate, a known carcinogen. The phototransformation products of triphenyltin hydroxide were more potent antimicrobials than triphenyltin hydroxide, suggesting that phototransformation reactions may actually increase potential impacts on microbial communities.

The broader impacts of the project were mostly focused on the education, training, and professional development of four female students. In particular, two PhD students, one BS student, and one African American high school student were involved with the project. These students led the experimental activities associated with the intellectual merit described above. All four students presented their work at regional, national, or international conferences. The research activities allowed the students to learn new skills that will benefit their future careers. For instance, aspects of this project served as dissertation topics for the two PhD students. The PI also conducted outreach to various campus organizations, including the Center for Women in Technology, the Meyerhoff Scholars Program, and the Office of Undergraduate Education. The aims of the outreach activities were to inspire, encourage, and guide students to undergraduate research opportunities. As one metric, the high school student involved with this project was accepted to UMBC, offered a scholarship from the Center for Women in Technology, and joined UMBC in Fall 2019.

 


Last Modified: 11/29/2019
Modified by: Lee M Blaney
